"Menopause typically occurs at age 50-51 years, but there is a large range. Menopause before age 45 is early menopause, and menopause before age 40 is known as Premature Ovarian Insufficiency (POI). \n\n There is substantial evidence that genetic factors play a major role in determining a woman’s age at menopause. It is likely that this influence is exerted through an effect on ovarian reserve. One of the most frequently studied areas is the association between mothers’ and daughters’ ages at menopause. Since mothers and daughters share 50% of their genes, if age at menopause is affected by genetic factors, it is likely that a significant correlation would exist between mothers’ and daughters’ ages at menopause. Based on the research in this \u0020"
the heritability of menopausal age was 44%, which is quite significant in knowing the ovarian reserve levels.

" Your Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) value is derived from a blood test. It has recently been shown that AMH provides an indirect measure of certain aspects of ovarian function, useful in predicting outcomes for asssisted conception attempts, and in assessing conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome and premature ovarian insufficiency."

"Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH) is a hormone that stimulates the growth of egg follicles, therefore it plays a vital role in helping to determine your fertility. 
 Any FSH value below 10 International Units per Litre (IU/L) is within normal ranges.
Elevated FSH indicates that your are either menopausal or approaching the menopause. What elevated means depends on where in the cycle the FSH measurement was taken.

 If the measurement was taken in the Early Follicular Phase (typically day three to five, counted from last menstruation), then any value over 10 IU/L is elevated, indicating approach of the menopause. 
 If the measurement is taken at any other time during the cycle, then a value over 25 IU/L is elevated. 
 Click on the following link to read more about the Science behind your FSH levels:  "

"Ovarian volume is a calculation/measurement of the length, width, and depth of each of the ovaries. Medical studies have correlated ovarian size with a woman's ability to respond adequately to fertility medications."

"Antral Follicles are developing ovarian follicles that have grown so large that they can be seen in ultrasound scans. 
 Your Antral Follicle Count (AFC) is the number found on a scan of your ovary. 
 A high AFC indicates that you have an active ovary that has many follicles developing towards being eggs that can be fertilized. For this reason an average or high AFC is often taken as an indication of good fertility, and low AFCs may indicate fertility problems. 
 AFCs will change every month or so, since the ovaries are not generally active at exactly the same rate. So a low AFC in one scan may be just bad luck, with later scans showing higher, more normal, AFCs. Conversely, a high AFC might just be good luck, so if at all possible, you should have more than one scan taken. "

"The cells that can become eggs are called non-growing follicles (NGFs for short). You were born with a fixed number of NGFs in your ovaries, this is your Ovarian Reserve. Typically there are about 400,000 in each ovary, but there is a large amount of variation so you could have been born with between 70,000 and 3 million NGFs. 
 There is a cycle that recruits some NGFs which grow into bigger and bigger follicles, but most of them die during the cycle. Only very few (about 400 for your whole reproductive lifespan) turn into eggs that can be fertilized. 
 It is believed that women who start with a high Ovarian Reserve lose NGFs quickly and women who have a low Ovarian Reserve lose NGFs slowly. This is because menopause happens for all women when there are about 1,000 NGFs left at an average age of 51 years. 
 This enables us to estimate the percentage of NGFs remaining for a woman of any age. The estimates are based on the Wallace-Kelsey model of NGF populations throughout life. Click on the link below to read the Science behind your results: "

"Smoking is linked to an earlier menopause, because in late reproductive age women at a given time, smokers are more likely to be menopausal than non-smokers. Research has shown that women who smoke more often than not reach the menopausal age earlier that non-smokers."
There is currently no concrete evidence that a high BMI will result in an adverse effect on the ovarian reserve.

Based on this result your fertility status is perfectly normal for a woman of your age. However, other indicators may affect your fertility, and you should consult a qualified physician for a complete assessment.

Based on this result, your fertility status is either below average for a woman of your age, or close to a minimum cutoff value, causing some concern. However, other indicators may affect your fertility, and you should consult a qualified physician for a complete assessment.

Based on this result your fertility status is either well below average for a woman of your age, or lower than a minimum cutoff value, causing concern. However, other indicators may affect your fertility, and you should consult a qualified physician for a complete assessment.

This application sends no information about your answers to any server. Your results are calculated directly on your device. The individualised results generated by MyOvaries is based on works published by renowned Medical practitioners and accredited academic laureates.\u0020

However, they are not responsible for the individual choices regarding treatment that you make based on the results using MyOvaries. Patients should always discuss their options for treatment with trained clinicians.

"Regular periods last 4 or five days, and happen every 28 days or so. \n If you don't have regular periods, you should consult a qualified physician before using any results from the answers you give to the other questions. \n This is because it is possible that your irregular periods are related to a fertility problem, even though the other details you provide give no indication of any problems with your fertility."

"Professor W. Hamish B. WALLACE MB.BS., MD (Lond)., FRCP (Edin)., FRCPCH., FRCS is a Consultant Paediatric Oncologist at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh and Honorary Professor in the School of Clinical Sciences and Community Heath at the University of Edinburgh. "

"His research focuses on the late effects of treatment on survivors of childhood cancer, fertility preservation, and clinical trials of Hodgkin's lymphoma. He is President of EuroNet, the European network for paediatric Hodgkin's lymphoma."
Thomas W. Kelsey BSc., MSc., PhD, MISFP, MISCB, FRSM is a Senior Lecturer at the University of Saint Andrews, and an international expert in biomedical mathematical modelling.

He specialises in data-driven knowledge discovery, computational oncofertility, and AI search. His other research interests include symmetry-breaking in constraints satisfaction problems, Casimir forces, and the enumeration of abstract algebraic entities.
Olalekan Baruwa BSc., MSc., is a software developer with a solid industrial experience in developing web and mobile applications.
He worked on this project under the supervision of Dr Tom Kelsey, gaining a Distinction award from the University of St Andrews in 2013.
